author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Tamil Nadu State Sand Lorry Owners Federation has suggested that the State government engage in direct sale of sand to control escalating prices.

Such a move would also lead to greater revenue generation for the government, the federation said at a recent press briefing.

Federation president S. Yuvaraj said that a revenue to the tune of nearly Rs.25,000 crore could be earned every year if the government took up direct sales instead of going through stockyard dealers.

“We will chalk out plans at a conference that would be held in the city on April 4. A separate department must be formed for sand-mining,” he said.

S. Thirunavukarasu, former Public Works Department engineer, said several waterways had silted up and sand-mining could be allowed to increase their carrying capacity.

Members of the federation noted that though the PWD had set the price of two units of sand, comprising 200 cubic ft, at Rs. 840, they procured it for Rs. 4,000 from the stockyard.

When the truckload of three units of sand reached consumers, they had to pay Rs.11,500.

Computerised

billing system

They said that of the 25,000 loads of sand being transported across the State, nearly 6,000 truckloads were brought to Chennai. Besides direct sales, the government must switch to computerised billing system as in Telangana.

The other demands, include a ban on overloading of vehicles and decreasing toll rates, would also be discussed at the upcoming conference, they added.
title: Lorry owners suggest direct sale of sand by government to control prices
